image.altText: A sign reading "Flinders Medical Centre - Main Entrance" with an arrow

props.synopsis: A document lodged with SA’s workplace safety regulator gives a glimpse into life on the frontline of an Adelaide emergency department. It isn’t pretty.

title.children: Is SA’s health system a hot mess? That depends on who you ask

image.altText: A life-like silhouette of a police officer

props.synopsis: A permanent memorial has been unveiled for fallen SA Police Brevet Sergeant Jason Doig, who has been remembered as a "kind, caring, generous and unique" country police officer.

title.children: 'An amazing legacy': Fallen SA police officer honoured with permanent memorial

image.altText: GettyImages-2170895522

props.synopsis: Ken Hinkley addresses the bad blood between Port and the Hawks ahead of their clash, as West Coast's coach defends his decision to play a rookie on Jesse Hogan.

title.children: 'I don't care': Hinkley addresses Hawks clash after last year's bad blood

image.altText: smoke emits from a fire at a hardware store in tumby bay

props.synopsis: The CFS saved nearby properties from serious damage when a hardware store in Tumby Bay caught fire on Saturday afternoon.

title.children: Fire razes Eyre Peninsula hardware store with estimated damage bill over $1m

image.altText: Dan Turner wears a black and yellow raincoat and smiles. His hair and face are wet.

props.synopsis: Dan Turner is ticking off a childhood "bucket list" dream as he races around the world in a boat he built during COVID lockdowns.

title.children: Man sailing around the world in boat he built in his driveway

image.altText: A worker welding some steel with sparks flying.

props.synopsis: Some Australian steel businesses have seen the price of steel drop sharply in the wake of Donald Trump's steel tariffs, but there are fears the glut of imported steel is threatening the viability of Australian manufacturers.

title.children: 'Deals to be had' as US tariffs send steel prices plummeting

image.altText: A blonde woman stands in front of a cityscape.

props.synopsis: Hannah Jayne graduated without an ATAR, then spent five years working at her local mine before she found her calling as a paramedic.

title.children: Young woman swaps high-vis for higher education to become paramedic

image.altText: A mosaic pattern on a sculpture of an Indigenous woman wearing a cloak with a baby and waves

props.synopsis: The dream of an Italian fisherman to pay tribute to the women of the South Australian town of Southend has come true with a mosaic monument recognising their role in the town's history.

title.children: Mosaic monument to women pioneers who helped create fishing industry

image.altText: Gold Coast renters Jazlyn, Melanie and Nahla Misuraca smiling at the camera

props.synopsis: An exclusive ABC analysis has revealed the nation's worst postcodes for renters, as well as the neighbourhoods hit with the biggest rent hikes since the pandemic.

title.children: Australia's worsening rental crisis is closer to home than we realise

image.altText: Peter Dutton Speech

props.synopsis: A Coalition promise to send public servants back to the office has been jettisoned, and plans to cut 41,000 Commonwealth jobs walked back significantly, in a mid-campaign backflip.

title.children: Coalition commits extraordinary about-face on 'end' to work from home

image.altText: A row of subsurban homes with a battery charging icon in the background

props.synopsis: A top energy expert says governments must ensure households that can't access subsidies for batteries still get a benefit, and must not be penalised.

title.children: Parties urged not to repeat solar 'mistakes' with batteries

image.altText: Nicolle flint in a grey blazer against a blue backdrop

props.synopsis: Ahead of the federal election, the Liberal candidate for Boothby, Nicolle Flint, reflects on the factors behind her decision to leave — and now return to — politics.

title.children: Can a former incumbent unseat a sitting MP in this marginal SA seat?

image.altText: the destroyed house of journalist Islam Meqdad that was hit by an airstrike in Khan Younis

props.synopsis: Strikes kill more than a dozen women and children in Khan Younis and Jabaliya, medics say, as Benjamin Netanyahu flies to Washington to meet with Donald Trump.

title.children: Israeli strikes kill 32 as US citizen shot dead in the West Bank, officials say

image.altText: Donald Trump holds a large board listing countries and the percentage of tariffs the US will impose on their imports.

props.synopsis: Officials also outline why the US president decided to place tariffs on uninhabited islands, as investors wait for major Asian stock markets to open.

title.children: Trump officials say some tariffs could last 'days or weeks'

image.altText: Murat smiling and adjusting his tie, wearing a dark suit, in a classroom.

props.synopsis: Murat Dizdar is a proudly working-class son of Turkish migrants on a deeply personal mission to win back students from the private education system.

title.children: Meet the education boss who wants you to pull your kids out of private school

image.altText: A range of doctors in red scrubs pose for photos at a strike where they hold signs.

props.synopsis: The doctors' union is going ahead with its planned action despite warnings from the Industrial Relations Commission and NSW Health.

title.children: Doctors say 'we don't have a choice' as they prepare for three-day strike

image.altText: A row of flags representing countries in the Pacific Islands against a blue sky.

props.synopsis: The Nationals leader says the Coalition would work with Pacific countries to "understand their power" with regard to China.

title.children: David Littleproud suggests 'practical' ways for Pacific islands to pressure China

image.altText: A photo of Kira. She has brown eyes and very long, plaited blond hair. She's leaning on a window that reflects her profile.

props.synopsis: Ukrainian children and wives have been apart from their fathers and husbands for more than three years. But families like Kira's continue to balance safety, duty and love.

title.children: Separated by years of war, Ukrainian families balance safety, duty and love

image.altText: People lining up to vote at polling place.

props.synopsis: The AEC is urging Australians to enrol to vote in the federal election to have their say in Australia's democracy.

title.children: If you haven't enrolled to vote, you only have a few hours left

image.altText: Rebecca Huntley

props.synopsis: This election campaign could matter more than any in recent history for one important reason – according to polls more Australians than ever before are unsure of who to vote for.

title.children: The major parties are helping create a generation of swing voters

image.altText: A man leaning against large ropes on a tugboat

props.synopsis: Nuclear, offshore wind, hydrogen and gas projects have all been slated for the NSW Hunter region but some may be scrapped depending on who wins the federal election.

title.children: Labor seats in this coal-mining heartland hang in the balance

image.altText: A woman in a crowd of Greens party supporters holding a sign that reads 'vote 1 the Greens'

props.synopsis: With Labor holding one NT seat on a slim margin and its grip on the other also in doubt, the Greens and a teal candidate are fighting to make history this election.

title.children: Greens and first NT teal candidate fight to shake up major party vote

image.altText: Darren Cheeseman wears a blue suit with a patterned shirt and stands inside a boat.

props.synopsis: Victorian MP Darren Cheeseman was forced to resign from the Labor Party in April last year, but since becoming an independent his participation in parliament has dropped.

title.children: Victorian MP's falling participation spurs call for parliament roll call

image.altText: SOLAR HOUSE KEVIN WEN

props.synopsis: A solar panel rebate program for Queensland rental properties announced by the LNP more than a year ago will roll out by the end of the year, aiming to save renters up to $700 a year off power bills.

title.children: Could this cost-of-living relief push up rent?

image.altText: Gout pointing at the camera

props.synopsis: You often hear athletics tracks described as "fast", but what exactly does that mean? And could it lead to a record-breaking performance for teenage sprint star Gout Gout in Perth this week? Tom Wildie investigates.

title.children: Why Gout Gout is poised for a blistering time on Perth's 'fast' track

image.altText: Oscar Piastri walks

props.synopsis: Tactical errors cost McLaren a win in the Japanese Grand Prix as Max Verstappen leads home Lando Norris and Oscar Piastri at Suzuka.

title.children: Piastri questions tactics as Verstappen wins Japan GP

image.altText: dad and son brush their teeth

props.synopsis: It's possible you've received conflicting advice from dentists over the years about whether to brush your teeth before or after your morning meal. We explain why.

title.children: Should you brush your teeth before or after breakfast? It depends

image.altText: Black and white photo of man sitting in chair at desk with two children and women standing close behind him.

props.synopsis: A regional Australian gallery isn't the first place you'd expect to find a neo-baroque masterpiece that belonged to a Russian tsar. Yet, with some mystery surrounding it, that's just what's happened.

title.children: The strange story of how a Russian treasure got to regional Australia

image.altText: A family of three sitting on, and leaning against, a big truck.

props.synopsis: A NSW cattle farmer is calling for buffer zones to prevent licensed hunting on the border of private properties amid a police investigation into a bullet hitting his parked truck.

title.children: 'Won't just be vehicles': Farmer's safety fears as hunting bullet hits truck

image.altText: A woman in a burnt orange cardigan leaves her vegetable garden holding a bunch of green leaves

props.synopsis: What about the people who change their career not to scratch some creative or philanthropic itch or make a truckload of money, but out of necessity — because illness or injury derailed or destroyed their ability to work?

title.children: Sarah's Tasmanian 'career change' sounds like a dream — until you hear her full story

image.altText: A woman in uniform leans over another person who is also in uniform, and lying down.

props.synopsis: Ukrainian soldiers and medics who have been on the front line during Russia's full-scale invasion over the past three years have come to the United Kingdom for six weeks to boost their battlefield medicine skills, and they have a message about ceasefire negotiations underway.

title.children: Ukrainian troops' ceasefire warning: 'It won't work with the Russians'

image.altText: Tim Tszyu smiles and holds up his hands

props.synopsis: Tim Tszyu conquers the demons summoned by his blood-soaked defeats in the USA. But now he has the bit back between his teeth, it might be best to stay home in future, and make people come to him.

title.children: Tszyu's dream homecoming a welcome tonic to American nightmare

image.altText: close up of old woman outside her home

props.synopsis: Residents in the outback town reflect on the shock and fear they felt as their once-dry town found itself inundated by floodwaters.

title.children: Jundah residents start clean-up after western Queensland flood disaster

image.altText: Shot of a smart meter in its box on the side of a house

props.synopsis: They were billed as the intelligent key to some sort of energy utopia, but smart meters are breeding confusion and broken trust, a watchdog finds.

title.children: Smart meters are breeding confusion and broken trust, a watchdog says

image.altText: Pope Francis sitting in a wheelchair. He's wearing an oxygen tube in his nose and a long white robe.

props.synopsis: Pope Francis has made his first public appearance since he was discharged from hospital two weeks ago after the most serious health crisis of his 12-year papacy.

title.children: Pope Francis makes surprise first appearance after hospital stay
